newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan says reporter held for "anti-state" acts.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan says reporter held for "anti-state" acts.

text.p: The Pakistani government on Tuesday acknowledged the detention of a local journalist held incommunicado for four days and said the man had been accused of "anti-state activities".

Interior Minister Shujaat Hussain told parliament that Humayun Far, Islamabad bureau chief of the Urdu-language daily Mashriq, had not appeared before a magistrate to be remanded in custody because he had been arrested under the Army Act.
Reporters briefly boycotted parliamentary proceedings on Monday in protest against government silence over Far's seizure by unidentified men near his Islamabad home on Saturday night.

The official APP news agency quoted Hussain as telling the National Assembly (lower house) on Tuesday he needed two more days to make a comprehensive statement, but he said Far had been "apprehended on charges of anti-state activities".

He said Far had been detained after a person already under investigation for anti-state activities told authorities that he had been receiving secret documents from the journalist "for onward delivery to other people".
The Rawalpindi-Islamabad Union of Journalists said on Sunday a state agency had picked up Far in what it called an attack on press freedom.
